toxins.name: The plants contain cyanogenic glycosides, specifically amygdalin
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Cellular Asphyxiation: When the plant parts (seeds, leaves, stems) are chewed or crushed, the glycosides interact with digestive enzymes to release cyanide.
    ◦ Mitochondrial Inhibition: Cyanide is a potent cellular toxin that binds with ferric iron (Fe
3+
) in the enzyme cytochrome c oxidase within the mitochondria.
    ◦ Oxygen Blockage: This binding disrupts the electron transport chain, effectively halting cellular respiration and preventing cells from using oxygen to generate energy (tissue hypoxia).
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ High Concentration: The toxins are concentrated in the seeds (pits), leaves, and stems.
    ◦ Low Concentration: The fleshy fruit typically contains very low or negligible levels of cyanide and is generally considered safe if the pit is removed.
    ◦ Potency & Onset: Toxicity is rapid; clinical signs of cyanide poisoning (such as respiratory distress, bright red gums, and collapse) can appear within 10 to 60 minutes of ingestion. Death can occur quickly due to hypoxia.• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual12
• Clinical Perspectives on Feline Phytotoxicology34
• Are Apple Cores And Seeds Safe For Pets? Get The Facts - Beyond Pets Animal Hospital56
• Can Cats Eat Apple Seeds? Is It Safe for Cats? | Dial A Vet

symptoms.name: Tachypnea (rapid breathing), dyspnea (difficulty breathing), or panting
symptoms.notes: Because cyanide inhibits the body's ability to use oxygen at the cellular level, the cat will gasp for air or breathe rapidly in an attempt to compensate for tissue hypoxia.Brick Red Mucous Membranes

symptoms.name: Bright red gums (mucous membranes) and cherry-red blood coloring
symptoms.notes: Unlike many conditions that cause pale or blue gums, cyanide poisoning causes the blood to be fully oxygenated (because cells cannot extract the oxygen), leading to a characteristic bright "brick red" color in the gums and tissues.Neurological Collapse

symptoms.name: Seizures, tremors, dilated pupils, incoordination, and sudden collapse
symptoms.notes: As the brain is deprived of usable oxygen, the cat may exhibit severe neurological signs progressing rapidly to coma and death.Cardiac Abnormalities

symptoms.name: Arrhythmias (irregular heartbeat) and hypotension (low blood pressure)
symptoms.notes: Cyanide toxicity can cause rapid shock and cardiac failure.Gastrointestinal Upset

symptoms.name: Vomiting, diarrhea, and salivation
symptoms.onset: 10–60 minutes (often the first sign before progression).
symptoms.notes: You may also detect an "almond-flavored" odor on the cat's breath. Gastrointestinal signs can also be caused by the physical irritation of the plant material.Death

symptoms.name: Sudden death
symptoms.onset: Rapid (often occurs before treatment can begin).
symptoms.notes: Due to the potency of cyanide and the speed of onset, death can occur quickly if the animal consumes a toxic dose of seeds or wilted leaves.

treatments.name: Cyanide Antidote Therapy (Sodium Nitrite, Sodium Thiosulfate, or Hydroxycobalamin)
treatments.description: Veterinarians may administer sodium nitrite to convert hemoglobin into cyanomethemoglobin (which binds cyanide), followed by sodium thiosulfate to convert the cyanide into thiocyanate, which is water-soluble and can be excreted in urine. Alternatively, hydroxycobalamin may be used; it combines with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12), which is also safely excreted in urine.
treatments.notes: Because cyanide toxicity acts rapidly (often leading to death before treatment can even begin), this specific antidote therapy is the most urgent intervention for a symptomatic cat. Sodium thiosulfate alone may be used in less severe cases.Oxygen Therapy

treatments.name: Oxygen Supplementation
treatments.description: The administration of oxygen to the cat, typically via a mask or oxygen cage, to support the animal's respiratory system.
treatments.notes: Cyanide prevents the body's cells from utilizing oxygen (cellular hypoxia), leading to respiratory distress. While the blood may remain bright red (oxygenated), the tissues are starving, making supportive oxygen therapy vital alongside antidotes.Gastrointestinal Decontamination

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis and Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: If the ingestion was recent and the cat is asymptomatic (not yet showing signs of poisoning), the vet may induce vomiting to remove the seeds or leaves. This is often followed by a dose of activated charcoal with a cathartic to bind any remaining toxins in the gut.
treatments.notes: Decontamination is generally performed only if the animal is stable. Inducing vomiting in a cat already experiencing seizures or respiratory distress is dangerous and typically avoided.Correction of Metabolic Acidosis

treatments.name: Sodium Bicarbonate Administration
treatments.description: The veterinarian will monitor venous blood gas levels to check for metabolic acidosis (high acid levels in the blood). If severe acidosis is present, they will administer sodium bicarbonate to correct the pH balance.
treatments.notes: Severe metabolic acidosis is a common and dangerous complication of cyanide toxicity that must be managed to prevent systemic failure.
